Article.ArticleTitle: Coordination chemistry of the Cu<sub>Z</sub> site in nitrous oxide reductase and its synthetic mimics.

AbstractText: Atmospheric nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) has garnered significant attention recently due to its dual roles as an ozone depletion agent and a potent greenhouse gas. Anthropogenic N<sub>2</sub>O emissions occur primarily through agricultural disruption of nitrogen homeostasis causing N<sub>2</sub>O to build up in the atmosphere. The enzyme responsible for N<sub>2</sub>O fixation within the geochemical nitrogen cycle is nitrous oxide reductase (N<sub>2</sub>OR), which catalyzes 2H<sup>+</sup>/2e<sup>-</sup> reduction of N<sub>2</sub>O to N<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O at a tetranuclear active site, Cu<sub>Z</sub>. In this review, the coordination chemistry of Cu<sub>Z</sub> is reviewed. Recent advances in the understanding of biological Cu<sub>Z</sub> coordination chemistry is discussed, as are significant breakthroughs in synthetic modeling of Cu<sub>Z</sub> that have emerged in recent years. The latter topic includes both structurally faithful, synthetic [Cu<sub>4</sub>(µ<sub>4</sub>-S)] clusters that are able to reduce N<sub>2</sub>O, as well as dicopper motifs that shed light on reaction pathways available to the critical Cu<sub>I</sub>-Cu<sub>IV</sub> cluster edge of Cu<sub>Z</sub>. Collectively, these advances in metalloenzyme studies and synthetic model systems provide meaningful knowledge about the physiologically relevant coordination chemistry of Cu<sub>Z</sub> but also open new questions that will pose challenges in the near future.
